title: 111_hr476
content: The Act titled "Veterans, Women, Families with Children, and Persons With Disabilities Housing Fairness Act of 2010" allows for testing for discrimination. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development will conduct a nationwide program to detect and document discriminatory practices in housing and mortgage lending markets based on race, color, religion, sex, familial status, disability status, or national origin. They will also work with fair housing enforcement organizations to address these issues. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development will evaluate the effectiveness of the program and issue regulations for applicants to describe their proposed activities, experience, and evaluation procedures. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development will report to Congress biennially on the outcomes of testing required for program evaluation. Additionally, an annual detailed summary of messages received by the Office of Fair Housing and Equal Opportunity will be provided. The Fair Housing Act allows the results of testing to be used by various entities to investigate and enforce actions against discriminatory housing practices. The Fair Housing Act allows testing results to be used for investigating discriminatory housing practices. Definitions for "disability status" and "familial status" are provided. The Act does not affect criminal law or the Truth in Lending Act. Regulations for tester training must be issued within 180 days of the Act's enactment. The Act allows testing results for investigating discriminatory housing practices. Regulations establish minimum standards for tester training. $15,000,000 authorized for fiscal years 2011-2015. Increase in funding for the Fair Housing Initiatives Program. The Housing and Community Development Act of 1987 is amended to authorize appropriations of $42,500,000 for fiscal years 2011 through 2015 for private nonprofit fair housing enforcement organizations. The Housing and Community Development Act of 1987 is amended to authorize appropriations of $42,500,000 for private nonprofit fair housing enforcement organizations. Funds allocated for private enforcement initiatives, education and outreach programs, and program activities under this section. Amounts appropriated remain available until expended for carrying out the provisions of this section. The Housing and Community Development Act of 1987 is amended to authorize appropriations for private nonprofit fair housing enforcement organizations. Regulations must be issued by the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development within 180 days of the enactment of this Act. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development will establish minimum training standards for testers of organizations funded for fiscal years 2011 through 2015. Regulations will be developed for evaluation of testers after public comment. SEC. 4. SENSE OF CONGRESS. The Sense of Congress is that the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development should comply with establishing a national education and outreach program for fair housing rights, use appropriated funds for such programs, and enforce fair housing obligations for recipients of Federal housing funds. The curr_chunk states that compliance with the Fair Housing Act is required, as defined under title VIII of the Civil Rights Act of 1968. Grants will be provided to private entities to study housing discrimination. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development will implement a grant program to assist organizations in studying and addressing housing discrimination and segregation. Eligible organizations can receive grants for comprehensive studies and pilot projects aimed at preventing or alleviating housing discrimination and segregation. The Secretary of Housing and Urban Development will implement a grant program for organizations to address housing discrimination and segregation. Organizations must submit an application, provide matching funds, and meet fair housing enforcement requirements. The Secretary will report biennially to Congress on the results of studies and pilot projects. The Secretary will report on comprehensive studies and pilot projects, along with recommendations for legislative actions. $5,000,000 is authorized annually for fiscal years 2011-2015. SEC. 6. LIMITATION ON USE OF FUNDS: None of the funds under this Act may be used for political activities, advocacy, lobbying, or travel expenses related to political activities or tax advice.
